author: By Thomas Rogers
title: ‘Dahomey,’ Documentary About Looted Artwork, Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
description: The documentary, directed by Mati Diop, was awarded the Golden Bear.
content: The top prize at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival was given to “Dahomey,” a documentary by the French filmmaker Mati Diop about 26 looted artworks that were returned to Benin from France in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Want to Lose a Lot of Money, Fast? Buy a Small Soccer Team in England.
description: The country’s lower leagues offer a tempting entry to ownership. But the sport’s economics mean even multimillionaires can struggle to compete.
content: Geoff Thompson knows there are plenty of people who want to buy what he has to sell. The phone calls and emails over the last few weeks have left no doubt. And really, that is no surprise. Few industries are quite as appealing or as prestigious as English soccer, and Mr. Thompson has a piece of it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Sun-Splashed Novels
description: An overbearing mother; a vanished sister.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: How to Vote in South Carolina
description: If you voted in the Democratic primary this month, you can’t vote in the Republican one, too.
content: South Carolina has no formal party registration, so registered voters can participate in the primary regardless of whether they identify as Republicans, Democrats or independents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Ross Douthat
title: Should We Fear the Woke A.I.?
description: Why the latest entrant in the great artificial intelligence race raised some eyebrows.
content: Imagine a short story from the golden age of science fiction, something that would appear in a pulp magazine in 1956. Our title is “The Truth Engine,” and the story envisions a future where computers, those hulking, floor-to-ceiling things, become potent enough to guide human beings to answers to any question they might ask, from the capital of Bolivia to the best way to marinade a steak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Michael C. Bender
title: At CPAC, Trump Invokes Clashing Visions of America’s Future
description: He used his speech to focus on a general-election contest between him and President Biden, not once mentioning his main Republican rival, Nikki Haley.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump laid out what’s in store for America should he or President Biden win the 2024 presidential election, using a Saturday speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference to cast one nearly utopian vision of the country’s future and one reminiscent of a postapocalyptic movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Nikki Haley’s Republican Party of One
description: Ms. Haley is performing about commensurate with how Pat Buchanan did in 1992 against George H.W. Bush. Mr. Buchanan, unlike Ms. Haley, was considered a contender.
content: In Rock Hill, S.C., last weekend, the biggest boom of a reaction came when Nikki Haley told the crowd, “Everybody’s telling me: Why don’t you just get out?” People basically responded with one long “no,” with one woman’s “Don’t give up!” sounding out above it. Ms. Haley responded instantly, “I will never give up,” and a big cheer went up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra D'Amour
title: Toxic Beauty Standards Can Be Passed Down
description: So many mothers and daughters are on an unattainable quest for endless youth.
content: When my best friend and I lived together 13 years ago, our shared bathroom had a handful of products: soap, tanning lotion, deodorant, toothpaste, potpourri and maybe, occasionally, a face cream that one of us found on sale at Walgreens. No serums, no toners, no anti-aging products. We never considered we wouldn’t be young forever. Our bank accounts were empty, our pores were clogged, our mascara wands were dry — but we were 22, and we were allowed to be messy. We were allowed to be young.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Reviving ‘The Wiz’ Through ‘the Blackest of Black Lenses’
description: The beloved 1975 musical returns to Broadway this spring, with nods to Black culture like second-line parades and Underground Railroad quilts.
content: Schele Williams first saw “The Wiz” when a tour of the original Broadway production came through Dayton, Ohio. She was 7 years old, and recalled it being the most “beautiful reflection of Blackness that I had never seen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Farmers Clash With Police and Macron at Paris Agricultural Fair
description: At the annual show where the French countryside comes to the capital, President Emmanuel Macron’s efforts to calm a monthlong confrontation were met with anger.
content: France’s farmers vented their fury at President Emmanuel Macron on Saturday as he arrived at the annual agricultural show in Paris, a giant fair long seen as a test of presidents’ relationship with the countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Molly Matalon
title: ‘Mom, You’re Not Grunge Enough’: Olivia Rodrigo Fans Thrash in the Desert
description: At the first stop on the Guts World Tour, fans added punk accents to feminine butterflies and bows.
content: On Friday, just outside Palm Springs, Calif., you might have thought a strange mirage had appeared: One or two zillion tweens descended upon an arena, all wearing platform Doc Martens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Says Indictments, and His Mug Shot, Are Helping Him With Black Voters
description: In a speech to the Black Conservative Federation, former President Donald J. Trump made express overtures to Black voters, whom he and his campaign are eager to win over.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, in a speech to a Black conservative group on Friday night, said he believed that the four criminal cases he is facing have earned him support from Black voters because they saw the historic unfairness of the justice system reflected in his legal woes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: 35 Hours for a 10-Second Clip: The Art of the TikTok Trick Shot
description: Videos of people executing elaborate, logic-defying feats with household objects have found an avid following on social media.
content: There are nights when Michael Shields lies awake next to his wife and thinks about Ping-Pong balls. He muses on their arcs and speeds, the ways they bounce off a wooden plank or roll down a Hot Wheels track. In the mornings he often turns his visions into reality, and millions tune in to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 24, 2024.
content: A headline with an article on Friday about Senator Chuck Schumer’s visit to Ukraine misidentified the city that Mr. Schumer visited. He visited Lviv, not Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger
title: Hard Lessons Make for Hard Choices 2 Years Into the War in Ukraine
description: Western sanctions haven’t worked. Weapons from allies are running low. Pressure may build on Kyiv to seek a settlement, even from a weakened position.
content: Two years after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the United States has the capacity to keep Kyiv supplied with the weapons, technology and intelligence to fend off a takeover by Moscow. But Washington is now perceived around Europe to have lost its will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: New York Mourns Flaco, an Owl Who Inspired as He Made the City His Own
description: Under Flaco’s favorite trees in Central Park and across the city, New Yorkers spoke of what the bird and his unlikely year of freedom meant to them.
content: Pjetar Nikac has been the superintendent at 267 West 89th Street, an eight-story apartment building near Riverside Park, for 30 years. What happened there Friday made it a day he wouldn’t forget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Kristi Noem and Vivek Ramaswamy Are CPAC’s Choices for Trump’s Running Mate
description: The conservative gathering’s straw poll is hardly predictive, but it can show which way political winds are gusting on the far right.
content: Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota and the entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy tied for the top choice to be former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate in a straw poll on Saturday at a prominent gathering of conservative activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Family Meeting
description: Your mother and I have something we want to talk with you about.
content: Your mother and I have something we want to talk with you about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Onstage, a Feisty Olivia Rodrigo Tests Out Life After Girlhood
description: The opening night of the pop star’s Guts World Tour had sparkle and abandon, but making her songs feel big didn’t require much besides the songs themselves.
content: As a pop star, Olivia Rodrigo wields a rather unusual arsenal of weapons. She is an acute writer and an un-self-conscious singer. She largely abhors artifice. She is modest, not salacious. In just three years, she has achieved something approaching stratospheric fame — a four-times platinum debut album and a Grammy for best new artist — while somehow remaining an underdog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Steve Paxton, Who Found Avant-Garde Dance in the Everyday, Dies at 85
description: With Judson Dance Theater and as the founder of contact improvisation, he expanded the possibilities of what dance could be, developing works around basic tasks like walking.
content: Steve Paxton, who helped radically upend ideas about dance as a member of the 1960s collective Judson Dance Theater in New York City, and who developed contact improvisation, a movement form that is now practiced around the world, died on Tuesday at his home in East Charleston, Vt. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Berkshire Hathaway Reports Profit of $97 Billion Last Year, a Record
description: The conglomerate saw major gains in its insurance operations and in investment income. But revenues at its railroad and utility businesses declined from 2022.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run for decades by Warren E. Buffett, recorded its highest-ever annual profit last year. But its chief executive found reason to blame government regulation for hurting the results of some of its biggest businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Amid Florida’s Measles Outbreak, Surgeon General Goes Against Medical Guidance
description: In a letter, Joseph Ladapo said parents at an elementary school with confirmed measles cases can decide whether their children should attend school.
content: As a cluster of measles cases grew in an elementary school in southern Florida, the state’s surgeon general sent a letter to parents that contradicted widespread medical guidance about how to keep the disease from spreading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Desiree Rios
title: As Medicaid Shrinks, Clinics for the Poor Are Trying to Survive
description: The end of a pandemic-era policy that barred states from pushing people off Medicaid is threatening the financial stability of the U.S. safety net.
content: Appointment cancellations and financial distress have become a constant at Bethesda Pediatrics, a nonprofit medical clinic in East Texas that is heavily dependent on Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Jonathan Weisman
title: Biden Caught in a Political Bind Over Israel Policy
description: His steadfast support of the Gaza war effort is angering young people and Arab Americans in an election year. But any change risks alienating Jewish voters.
content: The Biden administration’s reversal of Trump-era policy on settlements in the occupied West Bank reflects not just its rising frustration with Israel, but the political bind the president finds himself in, just days before the Democratic primary in Michigan, where a large Arab American population is urging voters to register their anger by voting “uncommitted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: How Many Tribeca Pediatrics Does a City Need?
description: Michel Cohen made the unglamorous job of caring for kids into a replicable, exportable aesthetic — to the tune of millions.
content: In 1994, Dr. Michel Cohen, a 35-year-old Moroccan-French émigré, opened Tribeca Pediatrics in a storefront on Harrison Street in Manhattan’s TriBeCa neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: All the Best Looks From the 2024 SAG Awards Red Carpet
description: Lily Gladstone, Cillian Murphy and Margot Robbie led the celebrity fashion brigade.
content: A few short months ago, members of the Screen Actors Guild wore jeans, shorts and T-shirts while carrying picket signs in the last days of a lengthy strike. On Saturday, they were at their red-carpet best as they arrived at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles for the 30th annual Screen Actors Guild Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A U.S. Call for a Humanitarian Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: While there are no good options for the United States on the war in Gaza, Biden’s leadership is indispensable.
content: Vetoing a United Nations Security Council resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza while circulating a softer hostages-for-cease-fire resolution of its own may have been the best of the bad options available to the Biden administration. President Biden is right to take this step. Given the scale of death and destruction in Gaza, and the prospect of more to come, he can take other measures as well that might lessen Palestinians’ suffering and loss of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Three Riveting, Slow-Burn New Thrillers
description: These novels hinge on split-second decisions that change everything.
content: This month’s thrillers pose intriguing questions. Can one seemingly unimportant decision change everything? What would happen if people could siphon time from the lives of others? And, most chilling: What awful things will parents do to protect their children?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Wayne LaPierre: Dapper as Charged
description: His financial misdeeds may have led to conviction, but his extravagant sartorial tastes proved little help to the former N.R.A. chief’s case.
content: You’d think Wayne LaPierre would have read the playbook. After decades in the spotlight, the former chief executive of the National Rifle Association could have been expected to know that, for public figures, conspicuous consumption is always a bad look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: In Speech at CPAC, Trump Will Outline a Thriving U.S. Amid a Second Term
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has so far largely campaigned on a dark vision of the United States under President Biden. A speech on Saturday will take a different approach.
content: As voters in South Carolina head to the polls in what is only the fifth nominating contest in the Republican presidential race, former President Donald J. Trump will give a speech on Saturday afternoon near Washington, where he is expected to focus largely on his anticipated general-election contest against President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Aleksei Navalny’s Body Was Returned to His Mother, Allies Say
description: The Russian authorities have transferred the body, ending a grim battle for custody of his remains.
content: The Russian authorities have transferred the body of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to his mother, his spokeswoman said on Saturday, ending a grim battle for custody of his remains, but it is unclear whether he will get a funeral that the public can attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Donald J. Trump Is Racing Against Time to Find a Half-Billion Dollar Bond
description: After losing two civil trials, the former president must find a bonding company that will vouch for him — or his real estate empire is threatened.
content: Donald J. Trump is on the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Rob Reiner on ‘the Greatest Single Performance’ in U.S. Cinema
description: The filmmaker says it’s one of Marlon Brando’s: “To this day I don’t know that there’s as good a performance as that.”
content: Rob Reiner was well aware that the Christian nationalist movement had achieved considerable political clout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Video, Nonbinary Student Describes Fight in Oklahoma School Bathroom
description: The police released video of the student, Nex Benedict, recounting the altercation a day before their death, which has drawn national scrutiny.
content: An altercation at an Oklahoma public school involving a 16-year-old nonbinary student who died the next day began after the student “poured water” on girls who had been making fun of the teenager, according to a body camera video interview released by the Owasso Police Department late Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Thomas Fuller
title: Netanyahu Issues First Plan for Postwar Gaza
description: The proposal, which calls for indefinite Israeli military control and buffer zones in the territory, rankled Arab nations and was rejected by Palestinians.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel released on Friday his most detailed proposal yet for a postwar Gaza, pledging to retain indefinite military control over the enclave, while ceding the administration of civilian life to Gazans without links to Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Marks 2nd Anniversary of Russian Invasion, Determined Despite Setbacks
description: European and other Western leaders gathered in Kyiv to pledge support for Ukraine amid U.S. reluctance, while its troops suffer growing losses on the battlefield, where the Russians have been gaining ground.
content: In solemn ceremonies and small vigils, state visits, stirring speeches and statements of solidarity, Ukraine and its allies marked the dawn of the third year of Russia’s unprovoked invasion with a single message: Believe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Anjali Huynh and Caroline Gutman
title: If Trump Drives Haley From the Race, What Will Her Voters Do in November?
description: Her supporters tend to be moderate and college educated — precisely the type of voters who have helped decide recent presidential races. We spoke with nearly 40 to see where they’re leaning.
content: Follow for live updates on the South Carolina Republican primary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Yale Tackle Isn’t the Best in the Draft, but Might Be the Most ‘Interesting’
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 24, 2024.
content: “I’m not just an Ivy League kid who is smart in the classroom. I’m smart on the field, too.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Flaco, Escaped Central Park Zoo Owl and Defier of Doubts, Is Dead
description: Let loose by an act of vandalism, the Eurasian eagle-owl died after apparently striking an Upper West Side building, according to the zoo.
content: Flaco, the Eurasian eagle-owl whose escape from the Central Park Zoo and subsequent life on the loose in Manhattan captured the public’s attention, died Friday night after apparently striking a building on the Upper West Side, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Hook
title: Political Memoirs Are Mostly Junk. This Critic Finds the Morsels.
description: In “The Washington Book,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning critic Carlos Lozada mines a genre known for sanitized prose to revealing effect.
content: The nation’s capital is home to a dreary literary genre, the Washington book: political memoirs, campaign biographies, policy treatises and other works by politicians, government officials and D.C. hangers-on. They’re often self-aggrandizing, poorly written or crushingly boring. Many people buy and talk about these books, but fewer really read them (except to scan the index for their names).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: What Christian Traditions Say About I.V.F. Treatments
description: While Catholic teaching expressly forbids in vitro fertilization, Protestants tend to be more open.
content: The Alabama Supreme Court ruling that embryos should be considered children has forced Americans to grapple with a mess of complicated realities about law, infertility, medicine and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and David Guttenfelder
title: Waiting for Serhiy
description: After nearly two years and only scraps of information, a Ukrainian family still hopes their son, a marine captured by the Russians in Mariupol, will come home soon.
content: His attempts to escape the Russian siege had failed. He and his fellow Ukrainian marines were surrounded, dozens of miles from friendly lines. They were nearly out of food and water. Some panicked, others quietly resigned themselves to what would come next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: TMI, Apple Watch! Why You Don’t Really Need All That Data.
description: Wearables can now track everything from heart rate variability to stride length. But access to so much data does not always mean better health.
content: Over the past few years, upping your exercise game has started to feel like getting a degree in data science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Henry Rono, Record-Breaking Distance Runner From Kenya, Dies at 72
description: Twice denied Olympic glory by his nation’s boycotts of the Games, he wrote himself into track history in 1978 by breaking four records in just 81 days.
content: Henry Rono, a Kenyan distance runner who was unable to walk until he was 6 after a gruesome injury to his right leg when he was a toddler but went on to break four world records in just 81 days in 1978, died on Thursday in Nairobi. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Man Convicted in Transgender Woman’s Killing in First Federal Trial of Its Kind
description: Prosecutors said the man was upset that word about his sexual relationship with the victim, Dime Doe, was circulating in a South Carolina town.
content: A South Carolina man was found guilty on Friday in the killing of a transgender woman in what the authorities said was the first federal murder trial of someone charged with a hate crime based on gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Winchester
title: The Story of a Deadly Avalanche, and Those It Claimed
description: In “The Darkest White,” Eric Blehm chronicles the 2003 disaster that killed the pioneering snowboarder Craig Kelly and six others.
content: I have no shame in admitting to neither a scintilla of knowledge of, nor any potential ability in, the wildly popular sport of snowboarding. So the unfamiliar jargon and the curious cast of characters in Eric Blehm’s latest outdoor true adventure story passed right over my head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Severe Frostbite Gets a Treatment That May Prevent Amputation
description: The F.D.A. recently approved the first therapy for patients in danger of losing their toes, fingers and other exposed parts of the body.
content: The first time Dr. Peter Hackett saw a patient with frostbite, the man died from his wounds. It was in Chicago in 1971, and the man had gotten drunk and passed out in the snow, his fingers so frozen that gangrene eventually set in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Sanitation Crisis in Gaza Spreads Disease
description: “It is a public health concern,” one U.N. official said of the lack of toilets for displaced people in the territory. “But the second thing is simply just dignity.”
content: In a sprawling tent encampment in Gaza, the Israeli bombs fall close enough to hear and feel. But daily life is also a struggle against hunger, cold and a growing sanitation crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Mackintosh
title: Cosmically Connected in a Journey From Deep Sea to Deep Space
description: A brooding biologist seeks transcendence in Martin MacInnes’s richly atmospheric, patiently unfurling novel “In Ascension.”
content: How to comprehend the vastness of the cosmos; how to comprehend not just the mystery of our place and purpose within it, but also our own lives as we live them on earth? Martin MacInnes’s Booker-longlisted third novel, “In Ascension,” is an elegiac voyage through these questions, a vaulting exploration of the interplay between the micro and the macro, the human and the otherworldly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: The Cost of Nuclear War in Space
description: Putting a weapon into orbit is not just a military threat. It’s also a risk to the billions of dollars pouring into the space economy.
content: Just before the Russian-Ukrainian war reached its two-year milestone today, U.S. intelligence agencies warned that Russia might aim a nuclear weapon at an unusual target: not any place on Earth, but satellites orbiting in space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Prominent Republican Seeks to Shield the Party From Paying Trump’s Legal Bills
description: Henry Barbour, a veteran R.N.C. member, is mounting a long-shot bid to keep the former president from taking control of the committee in order to block it from paying for his lawsuits.
content: A veteran Republican National Committee member has initiated a long-shot effort to prevent Donald J. Trump from taking over the party committee before he has enough delegates to become the presumptive presidential nominee in an effort to prevent the R.N.C. from paying his legal bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Police in Kentucky Arrest Man in University Student’s Killing
description: An 18-year-old Campbellsville University student was found unresponsive in his dorm room early Saturday and later pronounced dead at a hospital, officials said.
content: The police in Campbellsville, Ky., arrested a 21-year-old man who was wanted in connection with the killing of a Campbellsville University student on Saturday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: South Carolina Results Should Arrive Quickly Tonight
description: During the Democratic primary earlier this month, nearly all ballots had been counted by 10:45 p.m. Eastern time.
content: Good news for political devotees hoping to get to bed early: Barring unexpected snags, we should know the results of the Republican primary in South Carolina well before midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Maggie Astor
title: Trump is the overwhelming front-runner in South Carolina. Here’s the latest.
description: The polls are now closed in the South Carolina Republican primary and results should start flowing in momentarily.
content: The polls are now closed in the South Carolina Republican primary and results should start flowing in momentarily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce and Declan Walsh
title: Atrocities Mount in Sudan as War Spirals, U.N. Says
description: Rape, killing, torture: A stark report offers new evidence of horrific abuses carried out by Sudan’s military and its enemy, the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.
content: Bombs that struck houses, markets and bus stations across Sudan, often killing dozens of civilians at once. Ethnic rampages, accompanied by rape and looting, that killed thousands in the western region of Darfur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Macaroni and Peas, Buttermilk Roast Chicken and Shabu Shabu
description: Tired of comfort cooking? Neither are we.
content: We know that frozen peas are a freezer staple — they’re just as good as their fresh counterparts, and they’re always ready to add little pops of sweetness to skillet greens with runny eggs and vegetable pulao. But … what makes them such a good freezer staple? Why do they freeze better than, say, apples? A reader asked the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt for his new column titled, appropriately enough, Ask Kenji. You can read his full answer here while you boil water for his macaroni and peas, an easy and robust pasta dish that borrows from paglia e fieno (a heavy cream-sauced “straw and hay” pasta) and carbonara. (Kenji swaps some of the heavy cream for eggs to keep things light yet creamy.) Have a question for Kenji? Email him at askkenji@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Hamilton
title: Annie Hamilton’s Courtside Adventure
description: For a fleeting moment, she was the queen of Madison Square Garden.
content: Madison Square Garden went very quiet when my face appeared on the giant screen above center court. The silence was noticeable. A few seconds earlier, Kenan Thompson’s face had brought down the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Sex and the Capital City
description: While Joe Biden celebrates connubial sex, Republicans emblazon the Scarlet Letter.
content: “The Golden Bachelor” showed that sex is not just for spring chickens. Hearing aids and making out in a hot tub can go blissfully together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Dolnick
title: The Joy of Stoop Books
description: Why is it that books found in giveaway piles cast such a spell on us?
content: My life, like yours, I suspect, can feel like it has been ingeniously designed for the sole purpose of strangling serendipity. Work days are built around back-to-back meetings and video calls; evenings revolve around children’s bedtimes; date nights have to be scheduled weeks in advance; even phone calls to catch up with friends can take multiple rounds of back-and-forth coordination by text.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: For N.R.A.’s LaPierre, a Legacy of Guns and Money
description: Wayne LaPierre led the National Rifle Association for more than three decades. A civil court jury’s verdict on Friday underscored the extent to which he had enriched himself at the expense of the organization’s members.
content: Wayne LaPierre, who led the National Rifle Association for more than three decades, had long been the face of the American gun rights movement, a Beltway Clint Eastwood who insisted that “the only way to stop a bad guy with a gun is with a good guy with a gun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: For Car Thieves, Toronto Is a ‘Candy Store,’ and Drivers Are Fed Up
description: An epidemic of auto thefts in Canada’s largest city has left many residents exasperated, with some getting creative about deterrence efforts, such as installing bollards in home driveways.
content: Whenever Dennis Wilson wants to take a drive in his new SUV, he has to set aside an extra 15 minutes. That’s about how long it takes to remove the car’s steering wheel club, undo four tire locks and lower a yellow bollard before backing out of his driveway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liset Cruz
title: Guns and Goodies: How LaPierre Spent the N.R.A.’s Money
description: Evidence showed that the National Rifle Association’s leader lived well on donated money as he fought regulations on firearms.
content: The case brought by New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, against the National Rifle Association aimed to show how it used donations from gun owners across the country to pay for luxuries and exotic travel for its executives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: This Man Paid $9,000 for a Pair of Donald Trump Sneakers
description: Roman Sharf is one of the watch world’s best known dealers. Compared to the Patek on his wrist, the shoes were cheap.
content: When Donald J. Trump appeared at Sneaker Con in Philadelphia last weekend to promote a limited-edition line of gilded high-tops, there were a lot of boos in the crowd, but none coming from Roman Sharf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Few Good Solutions as Home Affordability Plummets
description: An economic analysis found that in several Canadian cities, prices would have to plummet, or incomes would have to soar improbably, to restore affordability.
content: Charles St-Arnaud, the chief economist at Alberta Central, the central bank for the province’s credit unions, started out his inquiry with a simple question: How far would prices need to fall, or would incomes need to rise, to make housing affordable again in Canada?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds and Madeline Gray
title: Their Weapons Against the Effects of Aging: Friendship, and Some Fancy Footwork
description: The Bodacious Belles, a women’s group in Beaufort, N.C., shows the difference a network of support can make in an aging America.
content: Martha Barnes’s home was buzzing. It was a Saturday in little Beaufort, N.C., time to get ready for the town’s Mardi Gras parade, and women were zigzagging around the house, applying makeup, laughing and calling out repeatedly for the Fireball Cinnamon Whisky sitting on the kitchen counter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saurabh Datar
title: Asian Americans Are Often Invisible in Polling. That’s Changing.
description: Without much survey data, there’s little information about what issues matter to Asian Americans.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine’s Deepening Fog of War
description: Two years after Russia’s full-scale invasion, Ukrainian leaders are seeking a path forward in the face of ferocious assaults and daunting unknowns.
content: The forecasts are anything but optimistic: The best Ukraine can hope for in 2024, many Western officials and analysts say, is to simply hold the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadya Tolokonnikova and Jillian Weinberger
title: Alexei Navalny Inspired Me to Start Pussy Riot. His Vision Is Immortal.
description: Nadya Tolokonnikova on the hope she still holds for Russia’s resistance movement.
content: Aleksei Navalny spent most of his life working toward a free Russia. Since his death, the Pussy Riot founder Nadya Tolokonnikova has been reflecting on her friend’s legacy. In this audio essay, she calls on the West to take seriously the threat that Vladimir Putin poses to global peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Fire in Valencia, Spain, Leaves Residents Homeless After Panicked Escapes
description: A fire that killed at least 10 people left many refugees from Ukraine without a home and others scrambling to rebuild their lives.
content: Vladimir Likhvan fled Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, hoping to find safety in Europe, only to watch helplessly as his new home was destroyed in the fire that raged Thursday through a high-rise apartment complex in Valencia, Spain, killing at least 10 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. and British Warplanes Again Strike Houthi-Linked Targets in Yemen
description: The Iran-backed group, which has been targeting global shipping routes, has proved especially difficult for the United States and its allies to restrain.
content: The United States and Britain carried out another round of large-scale military strikes Saturday against multiple sites in Yemen controlled by Houthi militants, U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘The Ones Who Live’ Picks Up Where ‘The Walking Dead’ Left Off. Where Was That Again?
description: The new “Walking Dead” spinoff, premiering Sunday on AMC and AMC+, builds on more than a decade of back story. We’re here to help.
content: The new six-part mini-series “The Walking Dead: The Ones Who Live,” the latest installment in the sprawling “Walking Dead” universe, premieres Sunday on AMC and AMC+. It finds Andrew Lincoln and Danai Gurira reprising their longtime roles as Rick Grimes and Michonne, the weathered survivors of a postapocalyptic wasteland populated by flesh-devouring zombies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: At Dance Theater of Harlem, a New Lease on History and Ballet
description: Robert Garland, Dance Theater’s new artistic director and longtime resident choreographer, presides over his first season at New York City Center.
content: Robert Garland has held many positions at Dance Theater of Harlem over many years — principal dancer, resident choreographer, school director, archivist and company webmaster. At long last, he has caught the prize title: artistic director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: It’s Not as Easy as Just Getting Biden to Drop Out
description: Democrats could pay a heavy price for bypassing the primary process.
content: In a recent episode of his podcast, my colleague Ezra Klein made the strongest case yet for replacing President Biden on the ticket with a new Democratic nominee. After listening to it, I disagreed with a few key points, and after discussing our differences, Ezra and I agreed that it would make sense to take this to the page, as it were.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Special Treatment
description: Scott Hogan and Katie Hale deliver a crossword that’s good for what ails you.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: SAG Awards 2024: ‘Oppenheimer’ Dominates the Night
description: The film took the top prize, and its stars Cillian Murphy and Robert Downey Jr. earned solo acting honors. Lily Gladstone and Da’Vine Joy Randolph also won.
content: Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer” scored three big wins at the 30th Screen Actors Guild Awards on Saturday night, adding even more industry prizes to its formidable war chest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Love Scene?
description: Cast an admiring eye on this scintillating themeless by Rebecca Goldstein and Rafael Musa.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Where to begin? I can’t be the only one who thought this after scanning this grid’s clues. I didn’t recognize a single factoid quickly, despite the specificity of most of the trivia questions; my mind didn’t click on any of the wordplay, either. Cue the cold sweat, which usually, and thankfully so, wakes up a few backup brain cells. In this case, they had a couple of ideas and good guesses, and then I slowly got rolling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: What to Watch in the South Carolina G.O.P. Primary
description: Nikki Haley trails Donald J. Trump by wide margins in her home state. Here are the things worth watching.
content: Follow for live updates on the South Carolina Republican primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: How Do I Evict My Roommates?
description: Even if your rental arrangement is off the books, tenants have legal rights that you need to consider.
content: Q: I lease a three-bedroom market-rate apartment in Brooklyn. I rent out two of the bedrooms, but the situation with my roommates is deteriorating for personal and financial reasons. The rent I charge them is way below market rate, and I’ll have to raise it significantly or ask the occupants to leave. I don’t have a written agreement with them. My lease doesn’t permit me to rent out the other rooms, and my landlord is unaware of this situation. What recourse do I have if the occupants refuse to pay the increase, or refuse to leave?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy D'Mello and James Estrin
title: I Spent a Week Rescuing Food From the Trash. Here’s What I Ate.
description: A climate-conscious reporter tried an app that connects eaters and surplus restaurant food. She got bargains, no booze and some pleasant surprises.
content: Food waste and I have a history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Grown in Oklahoma, Smoked in New York: Illicit Marijuana’s Legal Roots
description: Surplus weed produced in states like Oklahoma is increasingly ending up in New York, fueling its illicit market and complicating the state’s efforts to expand legal cannabis sales.
content: In the dead of night last April, state drug agents in Oklahoma intercepted an 18-wheeler rumbling east toward the Arkansas border smuggling 7,000 pounds of marijuana hidden in security camera boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Flaco’s Crash Might Have Been More Than Bad Luck. Here’s What We Know.
description: Buildings are a huge danger for birds. They also face other risks, including poisoning that can cloud their brains.
content: Flaco spent a year defying expectations, an owl born into captivity who quickly learned to hunt and fend for himself in the wilds of New York City. That ended on Friday when he flew into a building near Central Park. What went wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Fact-Checking Trump and Haley’s War of Words
description: Nikki Haley and her onetime boss, former President Donald J. Trump, have used false and misleading claims about polls and tax proposals while exchanging jabs on the campaign trail.
content: Follow for live updates on the South Carolina Republican primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How the Subway’s Weekend Problem Fixer Spends His Sundays
description: Jose LaSalle is known as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s “weekend service czar.” That keeps him racing across the city on Sundays, and trying to grab lunch with his wife.
content: New Yorkers who take the subway on Sundays may not know the name Jose LaSalle, but they might have seen him around in his orange safety vest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: South Carolina Republican Primary Results
description: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 South Carolina Republican primary.
content: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 South Carolina Republican primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Bloch, Saurabh Datar, Martín González Gómez, Ilana Marcus and Christine Zhang
title: Results: The Most Detailed Maps of the South Carolina Republican Primary
description: See results from every precinct and demographic analysis of the vote in the South Carolina G.O.P. primary.
content: See results from every precinct and demographic analysis of the vote in the South Carolina G.O.P. primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Josh Holder
title: Russia’s Brutal War Calculus
description: The costs of two years of war in Ukraine have been enormous. But many Russians are feeling optimistic.
content: The costs of two years of war in Ukraine have been enormous. But many Russians are feeling optimistic.
source.name: The New York Times
